HUD Launches Program to Address Discrimination --
The government says it has a new plan to tackle a significant problem for a number of Americans, housing discrimination.
A fair housing organization has shown that this issue is particularly problematic for African American hurricane evacuees.
They are often turned away, while white renters are given available homes or apartments.
Alphonso Jackson is head of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
He joins us via phone from Houston, Texas, where he'll announce the launch of a new national anti-discrimination ad campaign today.
Secretary Jackson, welcome to the program.
Thank you so much for having me.
Let's talk a little bit about the initiative that you will announce today and why you decided to put forth this effort.
Ed, Houston is the largest city that took the largest amount of evacuees.
They have been doing a very good job.
But we fail to make this clearly a national issue.
We emphasize where most of the evacuees went.

And so we're here today to announce that clearly HUD is going to take every appropriate step to make sure that no one is discriminated against on race, sex, or disability as it relates to those evacuees who have already suffered a very devastating blow with three hurricanes.
So we wanted to make sure that the country understood that as they spread out around this country, that they must be treated like any other citizens within the United States.
All right.
So what will you do specifically?
Through this campaign, you've partnered with the Ad Council to do what?
To make sure that television stations, radio stations all around the country air these ads.

And they have agreed to do this basically pro bono, because it's very important that people understand that these evacuees have been devastated tremendously, and they should not be subjected to any major discrimination in their effort to find decent, safe and sanitary housing.
And so we have gotten a real commitment not only from the Ad Council, but from New York State's Fair Housing Agency, but from around the country as to where they will work with us.

Now, you have found that, and we should note there have been a number of organizations who have conducted tests to find out about housing discrimination, it's not only for obviously, hurricane evacuees, not only for the South, but all over this country.
We'll get into some of those numbers in just a few moments.
But talk to me specifically about what your organization has found, what your department has found, in relation to minority evacuees and the discrimination that they are facing.
Ed, I think that's a fair question.
What we found out is that, yes, we've made substantial strides into curtailing the discrimination, but there's still a great deal of housing discrimination that goes on in this country.
In fact, we have the study from Chicago that demonstrated that.
And one of the reason we are making this effort is to make sure that they understand that HUD is not going to sit by and permit this to occur, especially to the evacuees.
We are very aggressively doing that.

We have a new Assistant Secretary for Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity, Kim Kendrick, who is a lawyer, who is very adept to all of the problems that are faced in many cases with discrimination, and we're going after those persons.
We've had great support.
I will tell you there are some different mayors of this city, such as Mayor Daly in Chicago.
He has been extremely - Mayor Street in Philadelphia has been extremely supportive.
Mayor Kilpatrick in in Detroit, and Mayor White right here in Houston.
So that's why we wanted to make the announcement that it was very important.
See, discrimination, in many cases, might be underreported.
And this campaign is to let people know where to go.
And we're going to have a number, Ed, if it's okay to give, that they can call us.
Sure.
We can give it now.
We'll put it on our website.

Hamilton Naki died this weekend in Cape Town at the age of 78.
He was not Dr. Naki, but he held an awful lot of heart in his hands.
Mr. Naki was a medical worker with famously skilled hands who assisted Dr. Christiaan Barnard in the world's first heart transplants beginning in 1967.
Dr. Barnard would install the heart, but only after Mr. Naki had carefully removed it from a donor and cleansed each cranny of blood.
Dr. Barnard became rich and famous.
Hamilton Naki was black and hadn't been able to attend school past the age of 14 under apartheid.
But after briefly working as a cattle herder, he hitched a ride into Cape Town and eventually found a job tending animals in the research lab at the Groote Schuur hospital.
He saw dissections there and, as he said, `I learned with my eyes.
Dr. Barnard revered Mr. Naki's surgical skills and insisted he assist him in all heart transplants.
The hospital had to oblige.
But when the world's press first took pictures of the world's first heart transplant surgical team, the hospital identified Hamilton Naki as a gardener.
By the time he retired in 1991, Mr. Naki has assisted in thousands of heart and liver transplants and taught thousands of doctors.
Shortly before he died in 2001, Christiaan Barnard finally revealed Hamilton Naki's true role on his team.
Mr. Naki finally received an honorary medical degree.
In a way, he was gardener whose hands cultivated life.
